column1: More than 700 employees and more than 600 students live in areas that were evacuated due to the recent fires in Boulder County. In all::: nearly 1:::000 structures were lost::: including the homes of dozens of CU Boulder students::: faculty and staff::: and reports of other damages are expected to rise.  Campus leaders made the difficult decision to begin the spring semester with fully remote instruction considering the fact that so many staff and faculty members are facing challenges such as managing illness::: securing housing::: working with insurance companies::: helping others in the community::: and replacing destroyed personal belongings from laptop computers to cars.  "Starting the semester in remote status::: rather than a two-week delay::: preserves spring break::: which students have indicated is integral to mental health:::" said Executive Vice Provost Ann Schmiesing. "Not delaying the start of the semester also preserves Maymester::: which cannot overlap with the spring semester due to federal financial aid guidelines. Maymester is an important opportunity for many students to take courses necessary for their progress toward their degrees."  Read more about how CU Boulder responds to impacts of devastating fires::: high winds and cold snap by clicking the link below.  COLORADO.EDU CU Boulder responds to impacts of devastating fires::: high winds and cold snap

Feed the Stampede serves as the food assistance program for the University of Colorado Boulder. We work to ensure students experiencing any level of food insecurity have the necessary knowledge::: resources and access to enough food to meet their needs in an emergency or on-going basis. All donations will support Feed the Stampede initiatives and will go directly towards fighting food insecurity on the CU Boulder campus. Money will be used to purchase food for distribution::: meal swipes for on-campus meals::: and grocery store gift cards for students in need. More Info ‚û° https://bit.ly/3pW2tie

We continue to be thankful for our Buffs from around the world who want to help those impacted by the Marshall Fire. Today we want to share information about the student emergency fund and the staff and faculty emergency fund.  The Student Emergency Fund provides direct financial assistance to students so they can pay bills if they've lost wages::: secure technology for remote learning::: and gain access to food and health care.  The Staff and Faculty Emergency Fund provides direct financial assistance for CU employees to gain access to food::: housing and health care.  If you'd like to donate to one or both::: you can learn more at the link below.  COLORADO.EDU We Are Buffs Together

We are grateful to all who have reached out seeking ways to help in the aftermath and recovery process of the Marshall Fire. Throughout the next few days::: we will be sharing specific ways you can help our Buff community. Today we are featuring the Buff Pantry.  The Buff Pantry is the on-campus food pantry and is here to support CU Boulder students who are experiencing food insecurity. The Buff Pantry is collecting donations and operating drop-in hours January 3-6 to support those impacted by the Marshall Fire.  You can also shop their Amazon Wish List. These items will get delivered directly to the Buff Pantry. The items we have selected complement items we receive from local food banks and provide much needed hygiene supplies to those in need at this time.  Learn more ‚û° https://bit.ly/3pSmI0m  COLORADO.EDU Buff Pantry Marshall Fire Resources

column1: Taking a look back at 2021 shows a community of perseverance. Buffs safely made a number of COVID-19 comebacks with favorite traditions; showed dedication to inclusive excellence; worked toward healing in the midst of heartbreak and injustice; welcomed newcomers such as Ralphie VI; won prestigious awards for scholarship and expertise; cheered on Olympians and remarkable student-athletes; listened to the perspectives of a variety of guest speakers; and more.  COLORADO.EDU Taking in 2021: Reflecting on the year at CU Boulder

"As we near the beginning of the semester::: we ask our campus community to act with compassion:::" Chancellor DiStefano. "For anyone in our community affected by this disaster::: please know that CU Boulder stands with you."  As this recovery begins::: we have decided to begin the spring term on Monday::: January 10 with fully remote instruction for the first two weeks of the semester. We are encouraging all students who live off-campus to delay their return to Boulder::: if possible. Faculty and staff are also encouraged to work remotely during this time::: in consultation with their supervisors.  Because of the impacts of the fires::: in combination with concerns about the COVID-19 omicron variant::: the broader Boulder area is not in a position to welcome back thousands of students over the next week.  Read Chancellor DiStefano's letter in its entirety which includes more details about on and off campus housing/student fees::: academic and work accommodations::: and COVID-19 considerations by clicking the link below.  COLORADO.EDU From the Chancellor - CU Boulder to begin spring semester remotely

At more than 140 years old::: 110 feet tall and 19 feet in circumference at the base of the trunk::: the "Old Main Cottonwood" has outlived and outgrown all other on-campus cottonwoods that were planted at the end of the 19th century.   Purchased in 1879 with a one-year warranty::: most recent examinations of the tree have indicated a likely steady decline and potential safety risks increasing in coming months if the tree is not removed.  However::: this won't be the last we'll see of the beloved Cottonwood.   With its above-average age and height::: it is an ideal candidate for cloning; cuttings were taken and rooted in 2014. There are now four six-foot scions in the campus greenhouse that will be planted in the coming years to help preserve the tree‚Äôs legacy.  Learn more about the "Old Main Cottonwood" ‚û° https://bit.ly/3ErR7Xc

column1: On Dec. 24::: NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration is set to launch its next flagship mission into space. column7: You will one day stand before God and answer for everything you have done. How will you do on that day? Here's a quick test: How many lies have you told in your life? Have you ever stolen anything? Have you used God's name in vain? Have you ever looked at someone with lust? Have you had sex outside of marriage? Have you ever had::: or been involved in::: an abortion?  Will you be guilty on Judgment Day? If you have done these things::: God sees you as a lying::: thieving::: fornicating::: blasphemer::: adulterer at heart::: and murderer::: and the Bible warns that God will punish you in a terrible place called the lake of fire: Revelation 21:8::: AV: "But the fearful::: and unbelieving::: and the abominable::: and murderers::: and whoremongers::: and sorcerers::: and idolaters::: and all liars::: shall have their part in the lake which burneth with fire and brimstone: which is the second death."  Yet God::: who is "...rich in mercy:::..." sent His Son the Lord Jesus Christ to suffer and die on the cross for all guilty sinners. We broke God's law and the Lord Jesus Christ paid our fine. That means God can legally dismiss our case and He can commute our death sentence. John 3:16::: AV: "For God so loved the world that he gave his only begotten Son::: that whosoever believeth in him should not perish but have everlasting life." Then the Lord Jesus Christ rose from the dead and defeated death.  Please::: repent of your sins and trust in the Lord Jesus Christ as Savior::: and God will give you eternal life as a free gift: Ephesians 2:8-9::: AV: "For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: Not of works::: lest any man should boast."

column3: I could care less about fairness or what ads I am getting. They are extremely invasive. I have walked by stuff at a hardware store and then gone to work and google ads pop up on my computer when I have never searched it. One was a specific refrigerator a salesperson was telling me about::: when I had no interest. Then 2 hours later I got an ad for that specific one on my work computer. I have had ads pop up for stuff I have only talked about in a verbal conversation. I don't want or need ads to be fair I just need them to go away. They should not be listening in to my conversations::: especially ones that are verbal when my phone is in my pocket.

column1: A CU Boulder Engineering spinoff company is on the verge of starting human trials for technology that could change the landscape for treating COVID-19 patients with one of the virus‚Äôs more severe complications. column8: Take care of my precious daughter.  Nothing can prepare you for saying good bye. Once again::: as a dad I must get ready to say good bye to my child. It's Hannah's turn. My little big girl is leaving a week from today for College in Colorado. Another one of my children that I was blessed to help raise. As with all my kids::: I will miss her dearly. I will miss the father daughter dances. The play time as her first prince. I will miss our time together::: sharing in her growth. I will miss the long trips to her gymnastics meets just as much as the memories of her first steps. Her first time riding a bike. Her first date. Her first drive. I always thought that raising a daughter::: protecting her was the hardest part. Its the actual letting go that is the hardest part. Hannah plays 4 instruments::: is an accomplished gymnast::: a high Honors student and is starting on her dream to be a DR. Dr Cramer. Lol. Sounds great. She will be studying Neurology::: to become a Neurologist. My other daughter Jocelyn has moved near her campus in Colorado. Jocelyn will attend the same University of Colorado to earn her PHD. Which means 2 Drs in the Cramer family Coming from a section 8 home::: a poor family that struggled to have food::: or heat or clothes::: this is something I did not ever dream of happening as a child. My only dream was to own a home. Have heat. Have food.  It's nice to see the hard work from my humble beginnings has turned into opportunity for my children that I never fathomed.  God bless Hannah on her Journey. He has certainly blessed me.

column1: From Tour de France elites to weekend warriors::: many cyclists ‚Äòdance‚Äô with their bike. Does rocking it side-to-side beneath them make them faster? Learn what researchers found out ‚û° https://bit.ly/3iCivZV
column3: You had to research this? You gain power by pushing the frame so you put more force into the crankarm that is on the side you're pushing away from. The movement of the frame coincides with the pedal stroke::: which is why you push the frame back and forth at varying speeds depending on gearing and terrain. You do the same on a mountain bike when putting down brief bursts of pedal strokes on a steep bit of trail or something.This frame movement puts more power down the drivetrain.  Now where's my grant money.

column3: First of all it is only tested for in competition periods::: the rest of the time party on Garth. But::: you can't legally drive under the influence correct? So what about those events that require accuracy::: unimpaired judgement and good reflexes for the safety of the athlete and other athletes? That would be most of them. Stoned equestrians jumping horses::: probably not a good idea? How about bicycle racing? How about javelin? Shooting? Archery? Would it help or hinder a pack of runners jostling for position in race? It's not just about performance enhancement. https:// www.usada.org/ athletes/ substances/ marijuana-faq/
column4: Another rule that should be addressed immediately. As the article says it can‚Äôt be lumped into the archaic category as ‚Äúall drugs.‚Äù As usual a committee of old folks yielding power over young athletes::: finely tuned athletes::: can‚Äôt differentiate between a number if things.

It was one of the worst massacres in American history::: yet::: for many Americans::: the Tulsa Race Massacre is not widely known. From May 31 to June 1::: 1921::: hundreds of white Tulsans‚Äîarmed and deputized by the local government‚Äîattacked::: pillaged and destroyed the thriving Black community of Greenwood::: Oklahoma::: also known as ‚ÄúBlack Wall Street.‚Äù  University of Colorado Law School Professor Suzette Malveaux represented more than 100 survivors pro bono in a 2003 federal lawsuit against the state of Oklahoma. Read about her experience working with massacre survivors::: why it took so long for them to seek justice and their continued fight in a recent Q&A with CU Boulder Today.  COLORADO.EDU 100 years later: Colorado Law professor reflects on Tulsa Race Massacre
column3: 100 yrs to understand :::find out and have pity on this action in history::: Wow"
column4: TULSA RACE MASSACRE Torrey Snow WBAL  There is so much hullabaloo about the Tulsa Race Massacre::: and the demand for reparations for one of the most violent organized operations against the black community. I am glad that we are finally shining a light on this::: but I wanted to warn you all that there is a reason that this incident has largely gone unreported though our US History. Many people are taking the perspective that the Tulsa massacre was the result of plain old racism and white supremacy::: but that is only half the truth.  When you read up on this incident::: as I have::: many years ago::: you find that racism was a convenient scapegoat for the real enemy::: which was a local unchecked government disloyal to the values of the US Constitution::: and unaccountable to the voices of the oppressed. The reason that you have not heard about the Tulsa Race Massacre::: is because for many years::: people like myself have pointed to this incident as a total validation of unrestrained 2nd Amendment rights. We have also held this incident up as a reminder for what happens when too many resources are piled up within Government infrastructure. Finally::: we point out the risks of economic disenfranchisem ent of entire communities within our urban environments.  Make no mistake::: it's no accident that you have not heard of this event::: until the race hustlers felt that it was safe enough to broach this discussion without risking their allegiance to major radical leftist policy points::: like mass disarmament of US citizens::: and unrestrained government authority. The truth is::: many angry people in this Tulsa mob were enabled by the local police department to carry out the will of powerful business interests who feared the economic strength of the black community. The role of government was so hard to hide in this massacre that Local::: State::: and FEDERAL government coordinated efforts to make sure that no one heard about the incident. Even aircraft were deployed to bomb local business communities.  People are using this incident as a rallying cry for reparations and advancing the cause of more Government programs. The lessons to learn from the Tulsa Race massacre is the exact opposite. It is a careful warning about the dangers of unrestrained government and a disarmed American people. It is also a example of how racial hate has rarely been the real motive behind most racial policy. The real problem here::: was that Greenwood was a thriving economic power::: with strong family units::: powerful community::: and relatively independent from the benevolent hand of government.  When allowed to function::: the African American community has been historically resilient::: prosperous::: and fiercely independent. Power structures have always been threatened by this capability::: and have always fought to hamper the ability of African Americans to thrive without the support of government. This is literally the most obvious truth before any student of African-America n history.  I encourage you all to take this day::: and reflect on the memory of the thriving economic engine Greenwood. And I further challenge you to reflect on where our urban communities are today by comparison. Bob Woodson Sr. of The Woodson Center notes in his book::: "Red::: White::: and Black - Rescuing American History from the Revisionists and Race Hustlers" that within 2 decades::: the Greenwood community rebuilt even stronger than before. This part is often left out by the race hustlers. I would wager that the members of this community never left their skepticism of government behind::: took careful preparations to adequately arm themselves::: and spurn offers of more dependence on Government programs. They would laugh you to scorn if you came them with restrictions on 2nd Amendment rights::: and would offer scathing rebuke to black leaders who worship at the altar of government aid.  And a final note. Ask yourself what the real difference is between the Tulsa Race Massacre is::: and the unmitigated disaster that has been US Urban policy in places like Baltimore. Ask yourself who has inflicted more economic devastation. Ask yourself where the most bodies are piling up. Ask yourself who has the most hopeless education future in the nation. And ask yourself::: why Greenwood was able to rebuild in less than 20 years::: but we we are coming up on 6 decades of economic devastation in our urban communities. When you are ready to confront those hard truths::: I'll be here to help equip you with better solutions.

A black version of the Chinese flag swept across African Twitter earlier this month::: as users replaced their avatars to express their anger at the government of China. They were outraged not only by widespread reports of coronavirus-rel ated discrimination against Africans in China::: but also by claims on Chinese state media that the allegations were "groundless rumors."  Posting under the hashtag #BlackChina::: Dennis Kiplomo::: a nurse from Kenya::: tweeted: "We expect the kind of hospitality we give to Chinese here in Africa::: be reciprocated in their home country." Another user in Kenya::: Peter Kariuk::: wrote: "We need a united Africa which will not be slaves of #BlackChina  Last month::: many Africans were subject to forced coronavirus testing and arbitrary 14-day self-quarantine ::: regardless of their recent travel history::: and scores were left homeless after being evicted by landlords and rejected by hotels under the guise of various virus containment measures. The incident caused a rupture in China-Africa relations::: with the foreign ministries of several African nations -\-\ and even the African Union -\-\ demanding answers from China. Yet China's official response stopped short of admitting that the discrimination took place -\-\ or apologizing for it. The Global Times::: a nationalist tabloid controlled by the Chinese Communist Party::: went one step further::: publishing an article titled: "Who is behind the fake news of 'discrimination ' against Africans in China?"  https:// amp.cnn.com/cnn/ 2020/05/25/asia/ china-anti-afric an-attacks-hist ory-hnk-intl/ index.html

column1: I thank President Kennedy for his service to the University of Colorado. Our campus will continue to focus on returning to a fuller student experience this fall; improving diversity::: equity and inclusion; and ensuring our fiscal resilience.  CU Boulder campus leaders and I stand ready with our colleagues across the CU system to support our University of Colorado regents as they embark upon this transition. "If certain acts and violations of treaties are crimes::: they are crimes whether the United States does them or whether Germany does them. We are not prepared to lay down a rule of criminal conduct against others which we would not be willing to have invoked against us." -\-\U.S. Supreme Court Justice Robert Jackson::: the chief prosecutor of the Nuremberg War Crimes Trials following World War II  THE NUREMBERG CODE  1. The voluntary consent of the human subject is absolutely essential.  This means that the person involved should have legal capacity to give consent; should be so situated as to be able to exercise free power of choice::: without the intervention of any element of force::: fraud::: deceit::: duress::: over-reaching::: or other ulterior form of constraint or coercion; and should have sufficient knowledge and comprehension of the elements of the subject matter involved as to enable him to make an understanding and enlightened decision. column1: Looking around campus you may feel a sense of calm::: but under your feet an artificial river flows::: holding a wealth of information about levels of SARS-COV-2::: the virus that causes COVID-19::: circulating in the world above.  Since waste water testing was implemented at CU Boulder in August of 2020::: a team of 35 undergrads::: graduate students and alumni have collected more than 3:::000 samples and run more than 4:::700 tests over at least 140 days.  The good news? The data is showing levels of the virus are over 1:::000 times less this spring compared to last fall. column1: SAFETY ALERT: The University of Colorado Police Department has been notified of two burglaries inside the CU Boulder Rec Center this week.  CUPD is investigating. Anyone with information regarding this crime or the suspect‚Äôs location is encouraged to contact CUPD at (303) 492-6666.  See CUPD's post below for more details:  University of Colorado Police Department March 31::: 2021 at 7:35 PM ¬∑  UPDATE 4/4: Last night::: Brent Roberts turned himself in to CUPD. He was the person in the photos that we shared earlier in the week in connection to this case. He faces felony charges and has been excluded from campus. Thank you to everyone who provided tips in this case.  SAFETY ALERT: CUPD has been notified of two burglaries inside the CU Boulder Rec Center this week. The suspect entered the facility by providing false information to staff and then stole or ransacked multiple backpacks from hallway cubbies and took credit cards and cash from the backpacks. One of the credit cards was used to purchase more than $400 in Visa gift cards at a local convenience store.  CUPD is investigating these incidents. Anyone with information regarding this crime or the suspect‚Äôs location is encouraged to contact CUPD at (303) 492-6666. If you wish to share information anonymously::: information on contacting Northern Colorado Crime Stoppers by phone or email is available at www.colorado.edu/police/records-reports/anonymous-reporting.  https://www.colorado.edu/police/node/2289/

column1: Today::: Chancellor DiStefano condemned the acts of violence in the Atlanta area and called on our community to unite against racism and discrimination and to stand in solidarity with our Asian::: Asian American and Pacific Islander communities. ‚ÄúWe must join together as a university community in our condemnation of this act of violence and against a legacy of xenophobia and discrinination against Asians::: Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders in the United States. We recognize that since the pandemic began::: they have been impacted by increasing violence and intimidation driven by racism‚Äì‚Äìacts that have spurred greater fear and anxiety for many." To read the chancellor‚Äôs message in its entirety and for a list of campus support resources::: reading materials::: community campaigns and information about the April 7 event hosted by the Center for Inclusion and Social Change::: ‚ÄúHow to Talk About What Matters: Anti-Asian Racism in the Time of COVID:::‚Äù click the link below. As we acknowledge the pain that anti-Asian discrimination is causing in our campus community::: around the nation and across the globe::: we must understand and recognize that many of our students::: faculty and staff may be experiencing fear::: anxiety and anger following today‚Äôs tragic events and other attacks. As a community::: we must unite against racism::: discrimination and violence in our community and beyond. Almost every area in the world::: including Colorado‚Äôs Rocky Mountains::: has been affected in the past 200 years by increased acidic nutrients::: like nitrogen::: contained in rain and snow. Researchers from CU Boulder have found that Niwot Ridge‚Äîa high alpine area of the Rocky Mountains::: east of the Continental Divide‚Äîis slowly recovering from increased acidity caused by vehicle emissions in Colorado‚Äôs Front Range. column1: Anosmia::: also known as smell blindness::: is the loss of the ability to detect one or more smells and is a far more prevalent symptom of COVID-19 than fever. Roy Parker::: a professor of biochemistry and director of CU‚Äôs BioFrontiers Institute and Dan Larremore::: an assistant professor of computer science::: teamed up with CU Boulder alumnus Derek Toomre::: a professor at the Yale School of Medicine to develop a simple::: scratch-and-sniff test could play a key role in curbing the spread of COVID-19. This year has been different::: so our State of the Campus message is different.  When I look back on 2020::: I‚Äôll reflect on the hardships::: but also on the resiliency of all of you and our great institution. I‚Äôll always remember the strengthened fabric of our community and carry with me the lessons learned to benefit today‚Äôs and tomorrow‚Äôs Buffs.  We have engaged with our broader community throughout the year in unprecedented ways. Difficult decisions were made a little easier because of this ongoing conversation. Along the way::: we clarified our priorities and gained a new appreciation for what‚Äôs important‚Äîeach other‚Äîwhile continuing to lead::: innovate::: impact and shape tomorrow‚Äôs leaders.  Stay tuned early in the new year as I‚Äôm joined in conversation by campus leaders and experts to pull the curtain back on our three biggest priorities: how to build a more anti-racist community::: become more fiscally resilient and create a more COVID-19-ready campus. Look for opportunities to engage on these issues throughout the spring semester.  In the meantime::: please accept my deepest appreciation for everything you‚Äôve done under the most difficult circumstances.  We are Buffs together:::  Phil  For more::: please visit: https://www.colorado.edu/stateofcampus

column6: I took "US History since 1865" back in 1991. The professor was Michael Mann::: I think. He was the first educator to ever challenge the status quo positions from education and make me really look at political history with a critical eye. He opened my eyes to just how awful FDR was::: and that the policies of Nixon were actually really good for the country. And many other things. His class forever changed me::: and made me a better::: smarter person.

column8: Dr Elisa Facio was my amazing advisor and professor in Ethnic Studies. She & Dr. Salvador Rodr√≠guez Pino are the reason I now teach Chicana/o Studies & introduction to Ethnic Studies! May they both RIP! Hats off to all the educators at the BUENO Center as well- we are awesome! SKO Buffs
column9: I was a Poli Sci major::: graduating in 1968. The best ever profs I actually took classes from were Richard Wilson::: Constitutional Law::: and John Buechner::: American Foreign Policy. Professor Buechner went on to become Chancellor of CU Denver campus and later President of the University at Boulder. These were two Professors whose teaching methods steered clear of politics of the moment::: focusing instead on the respective roles of the Supreme Court in American government and the role of American foreign policy in shaping economic & political enlightenment in countries around the world. Their teaching ignored the immediacy of the Vietnam War::: the raw wounds of JFK's assassination and the ensuing criticism::: focusing entirely on the roots of the American judicial system and the policies of recent & incipient administrations with respect to foreign governments::: many throwing off the fetters of colonialism and seeking government structure to guide new governments. I don't recall many judgments being passed in any of the classes I had by these two profs::: making for a true academic exercise of their respective coursework. I enjoyed Constitutional Law because of Professor Wilson's class so much that I recently purchased the Sixth Edition of Constitutional Law casebook/ commentary::: now more than twice the size of my '68 text and about 3 lb of Court history. Hope that looking back at deceased professors is also worthy of consideration; both lectured and participated in government at a moment of enormous change in nations and leaders::: and the work these two did have helped me understand the strains and the changes and to discuss intelligently::: rationally::: those changes as well as their causes and direction toward new government forms. I focused::: as both profs did::: on the big picture view as I served in Vietnam and Fort Benning as an Army editor and reporter at the time of the My Lai Massacre::: Jane Fonda's appearance as a model American astride a Russian-made anti-aircraft gun in Hanoi::: internal Army racial tensions and the heroics of those of us in harm's way on behalf of our Country and in service to each other. (A word about the recent passing of W Harold "Sonny" Flowers::: a friend in our senior year at CU. Sonny later attended CU Law and practiced in Boulder. Sonny was a Black man committed to making this a better::: more just::: world; I ran into him by chance in Vietnam; we shook hands::: spoke for a few minutes as friends::: then parted. I never saw him again::: but his name has often appeared in the Coloradan in years since. Sic Transit Gloria Mundi. But an exceptional transit it was for Sonny.)

column1: New findings from a group scientists which include CU Boulder researchers found with a bit of planning and proper management today::: humans could help to keep fisheries productive::: even in the event of a nuclear war‚Äîpotentially allowing these vital sources of food to make up for the loss of crops on land.  The study is part of a multi-year project led by CU Boulder Professor Brian Toon and Alan Robock of Rutgers University to examine the global costs of a potential nuclear war. The team‚Äôs latest findings::: however::: come with a rare silver lining::: said Kim Scherrer::: one of two lead authors of the new study. COLORADO.EDU Scientists explore how to protect fisheries::: food supply in event of nuclear war

column1: Flour beetles have been studied since the early 1900s and are a model organism in ecology. In the same way that fruit flies are used as a model organism for studying genetics::: flour beetles can represent the fundamental ecology of most organisms and their responses in the lab can be applied to larger ecological trends and patterns in the natural world.  As species across the world adjust where they live in response to climate change::: they will come into competition with other species that could hamper their ability to keep up with the pace of this change::: according to new CU Boulder-led research.  COLORADO.EDU Tiny beetles a bellwether of ecological disruption by climate change

CU Boulder is operating on a delayed schedule today::: Oct. 26::: 2020::: due to weather conditions. The campus will open at 10 a.m. Any class or lab scheduled to start at or after 10 a.m.::: will meet as usual following the late opening. Employees working remotely are also on the same delayed start. Classes and labs (in-person and remote) that begin before 10 a.m. are canceled::: including those continuing past the late opening. Dining halls and residence halls will remain open as crews clear sidewalks and roads. For updates::: monitor http://alerts.colorado.edu and CU Boulder social media channels.

column13: The Great Barrington Declaration  As infectious disease epidemiologists and public health scientists we have grave concerns about the damaging physical and mental health impacts of the prevailing COVID-19 policies::: and recommend an approach we call Focused Protection.  Coming from both the left and right::: and around the world::: we have devoted our careers to protecting people.  Current lockdown policies are producing devastating effects on short and long-term public health.  The results (to name a few) include lower childhood vaccination rates::: worsening cardiovascular disease outcomes::: fewer cancer screenings and deteriorating mental health ‚Äì leading to greater excess mortality in years to come::: with the working class and younger members of society carrying the heaviest burden.  Keeping students out of school is a grave injustice.  Keeping these measures in place until a vaccine is available will cause irreparable damage::: with the underprivileged disproportionat ely harmed.  Fortunately::: our understanding of the virus is growing. We know that vulnerability to death from COVID-19 is more than a thousand-fold higher in the old and infirm than the young.  Indeed::: for children::: COVID-19 is less dangerous than many other harms::: including influenza.  As immunity builds in the population::: the risk of infection to all ‚Äì including the vulnerable ‚Äì falls.  We know that all populations will eventually reach herd immunity ‚Äì i.e. the point at which the rate of new infections is stable ‚Äì and that this can be assisted by (but is not dependent upon) a vaccine.  Our goal should therefore be to minimize mortality and social harm until we reach herd immunity.  The most compassionate approach that balances the risks and benefits of reaching herd immunity::: is to allow those who are at minimal risk of death to live their lives normally to build up immunity to the virus through natural infection::: while better protecting those who are at highest risk.  We call this Focused Protection.  Adopting measures to protect the vulnerable should be the central aim of public health responses to COVID-19. By way of example::: nursing homes should use staff with acquired immunity and perform frequent PCR testing of other staff and all visitors. Staff rotation should be minimized.  Retired people living at home should have groceries and other essentials delivered to their home. When possible::: they should meet family members outside rather than inside.  A comprehensive and detailed list of measures::: including approaches to multi-generatio nal households::: can be implemented::: and is well within the scope and capability of public health professionals.  Those who are not vulnerable should immediately be allowed to resume life as normal.  Simple hygiene measures::: such as hand washing and staying home when sick should be practiced by everyone to reduce the herd immunity threshold.  Schools and universities should be open for in-person teaching.  Extracurricular activities::: such as sports::: should be resumed.  Young low-risk adults should work normally::: rather than from home.  Restaurants and other businesses should open.  Arts::: music::: sport and other cultural activities should resume.  People who are more at risk may participate if they wish::: while society as a whole enjoys the protection conferred upon the vulnerable by those who have built up herd immunity.  On October 4::: 2020::: this declaration was authored and signed in Great Barrington::: United States::: by:  Dr. Martin Kulldorff::: professor of medicine at Harvard University::: a biostatistician ::: and epidemiologist with expertise in detecting and monitoring of infectious disease outbreaks and vaccine safety evaluations.  Dr. Sunetra Gupta::: professor at Oxford University::: an epidemiologist with expertise in immunology::: vaccine development::: and mathematical modeling of infectious diseases.  Dr. Jay Bhattacharya::: professor at Stanford University Medical School::: a physician::: epidemiologist::: health economist::: and public health policy expert focusing on infectious diseases and vulnerable populations.  Please see link for article and additional support professionals:  https:// gbdeclaration.or g/

Correction: In our excitement for Dr. Doudna::: we imprecisely stated she is an alumna of CU Boulder. While Dr. Doudna did research in the Cech Lab from '91-'94::: she did not graduate with a degree from CU. Still::: we're very excited to have played a role in this ex-Cechies' academic journey!  Nobel Prize October 7::: 2020 at 1:48 AM ¬∑  BREAKING NEWS The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences has decided to award the 2020 Nobel Prize in Chemistry to Emmanuelle Charpentier and Jennifer A. Doudna ‚Äúfor the development of a method for genome editing.‚Äù  Emmanuelle Charpentier and Jennifer A. Doudna have discovered one of gene technology‚Äôs sharpest tools: the CRISPR/Cas9 genetic scissors. Using these::: researchers can change the DNA of animals::: plants and microorganisms with extremely high precision. This technology has had a revolutionary impact on the life sciences::: is contributing to new cancer therapies and may make the dream of curing inherited diseases come true.  Researchers need to modify genes in cells if they are to find out about life‚Äôs inner workings. This used to be time-consuming::: difficult and sometimes impossible work. Using the CRISPR/Cas9 genetic scissors::: it is now possible to change the code of life over the course of a few weeks.  Since Charpentier and Doudna discovered the CRISPR/Cas9 genetic scissors in 2012 their use has exploded. This tool has contributed to many important discoveries in basic research::: and plant researchers have been able to develop crops that withstand mould::: pests and drought. In medicine::: clinical trials of new cancer therapies are underway::: and the dream of being able to cure inherited diseases is about to come true. These genetic scissors have taken the life sciences into a new epoch and::: in many ways::: are bringing the greatest benefit to humankind.  Press release: https://bit.ly/2Hzxp4h Popular information: https://bit.ly/3cNgeHJ Advanced information: https://bit.ly/2HwL3oE

column30: Reading the actuarial reports of 60-70% reduction in required reserves for Covid 19 Life insurance early death payouts is sobering. While the town is in mass Hysteria-on-the -Hill those mainly dying outside OAP homes are poor with low insurance. Often these are minorities who of course are disproportionat ely poor in this country. The issue of course is long-term health conditions often associated with poverty. All the screeching about wearing masks is fine by all (just common sense) but by failing to address the fundamentals of poverty as a cause death and illness the numbers will only change slowly while we burn the economy and kids lives. We will say cancers go up because of screening delays. Actuaries are brutal people to spend time with because they price death for the insurance market. On this Covid they are worth listening to. The rest of it is just flapping about.  If we assume death risk-pricers know what they are doing we should be targeting the vaccine to those most vulnerable AND aggressively promoting health in those groups as the overriding priority. I imagine the cost to the economy could have paid for this many times over.  One might also imagine that the loss of elders and social cohesion in those groups is a contributor to despair on the streets. Triage in those groups will surely be the best $$$ spent long term.

column82: Added restrictions for students living in ‚Äúidentified properties‚Äù.  Stay-At-Home Requirements for Identified Properties Residents of identified properties are prohibited from:  Leaving their residence except for Essential Activities and Essential Travel. Using any mode of public transportation or rideshare (e.g. bus::: plane::: taxi::: train::: Uber::: Lyft). Allowing any non-household member to enter the residence::: unless they are an Essential Visitor. Moving from their residence unless relocating to an alternate location (see below) Congregating in common areas of the residence. Face Coverings must be worn in common areas::: and residents must social distance Participate in outdoor exercise with a group in any form Travel for outdoor exercise by motorized means Going to work unless they believe they will experience food insecurity or housing insecurity. If so::: contact Public Health immediately at 303-413-7523::: or 303-413-7517 after work hours::: or email healthinfo@boul dercounty.org. Stay-at-Home Residents must:  Stay within walking distance of their residence Make every effort to avoid other people Wear a face covering at all times Report their name and address to the City of Boulder within 24 hours of being given the Order Notify Boulder County Public Health before relocating to an alternate location and: Comply with the Stay-at-Home requirements and any additional quarantine requirements of the local jurisdiction Not return to the residence for any reason until the Order expires. Notify all other occupants at the alternative location about the requirements before starting travel Individuals who are in isolation (tested positive for COVID-19 or exhibiting COVID-19 symptoms) may not move to an alternative location. Stay-at-Home Residents may:  Receive contactless food delivery or pickup curbside orders from restaurants Stay-at-Home Residents do not include:  Minor dependents who live with the adult legally responsible for them The adult responsible for the minor dependent Note: anyone who believes following the Order will create food or housing insecurity should contact Public Health at healthinfo@boul dercounty.org::: 303-413-7523 during normal weekday work hours::: or 303-413-7517 after work hours.
column83: I have no connection with BCPH. I'm telling my student that campus/boulder isn't safe and she should have an escort if she feels unsafe.. like her roommate or boyfriend. ... Boulder County Public Health After working with the attorneys::: we wanted to share some updates and clarifications on the new Public Health Order. Please remember the purpose of the order is to keep people separated so that the virus does not spread. This is good for everyone in the community::: both by keeping the COVID-19 infection rate down::: and by helping businesses stay open at the current level. If the new infection rate remans high::: businesses might be required to reduce the services they currently offer. The worst case scenario is we could all be put back under a Stay-At-Home Order by the state. This is not about finding loopholes to the Order::: but helping to reduce the rate of infection. * Public Transportation & Ride Sharing (like Uber) for people not living at a Restricted Address The purpose of the order is to keep people separated so that the virus does not spread::: so we‚Äôd like everyone to do their best to find alternatives for the next 13 days. If it's necessary to use these services::: or share a ride in a personal vehicle::: wear a mask and stay as socially distanced as possible. After reaching your destination you need to keep separate from others::: so a gathering does not take place. * Transportation for Medical Emergencies for people living at a Restricted Address. If it is a true medical emergency to get medical care::: you can use Ride Sharing::: etc. Wear a mask and keep a social distance. Please remember::: the purpose of the order is to keep people separated so the virus does not continue to spread. *Escorts during the night or other unsafe times The purpose of the order is to keep people separated so that the virus does not spread. We‚Äôd like everyone to do their best to find alternatives for the next 13 days.

column1: Because of a significant rise in COVID-19 cases linked primarily to CU Boulder students::: and to protect the health and safety of the community::: our campus is fully cooperating with the Boulder County Public Health recommendation that all of our local undergraduate and graduate students immediately self-quarantine for two weeks in their campus-area home or residence hall. CU Boulder will be enforcing this measure::: which expires at 11:59 p.m. on Tuesday::: Sept. 29.  Quarantine is not the same as isolation. It is avoiding in-person interactions with others::: monitoring yourself for symptoms and following health precautions. Students may leave their residences only to attend in-person classes::: labs::: research activities and intercollegiate athletic trainings; obtain food::: medicine::: medical care::: including seeking COVID-19-related testing; work and taking children to school/child care; and exercise by themselves (the Rec Center remains open).  The campus will continue to support students with dining::: monitoring::: testing::: medical care and mental health services. Additionally::: virtual events and programs will be offered for students to engage outside of the classroom in the safest way possible. column1: Our CU Boulder testing::: contact tracing and Boulder County Public Health (BCPH) collaborations alerted us this morning to a potential increase in positive COVID-19 cases among our on and off-campus students.  We are concerned with this likely increase in positive cases over the past 24 hours::: and we anticipate the increase in confirmed positive cases will continue through the remainder of the week.  We expected spikes like this might occur and have planned for this possibility. As we did during the increase in off-campus cases earlier this summer::: we are rapidly employing our testing::: contact tracing and isolation protocols in partnership with BCPH to contain the potential for community spread.  The next few days will be critical to our ability to maintain our current operating status. It is imperative that we all continue to follow public health orders::: avoid large gatherings::: wear masks and practice physical distancing.  The measures we have put into place ‚Äî wastewater monitoring::: surveillance and diagnostic testing::: contact tracing and isolation ‚Äî have been working to help us identify potential outbreaks early::: minimize the risk of community spread and care for our infected students. column13: The email sent to the students: Dear Students:::  For many of us::: the excitement of starting a new academic year has also brought a level of uncertainty and stress as we continue to navigate around a global pandemic. To our students who are following health and safety protocols::: thank you! I know it‚Äôs been challenging as we reunite with friends and classmates. I appreciate your ongoing decision to do the right thing by wearing a face covering::: avoiding large gatherings and keeping each other safe.  To those of you who are choosing to disregard health and safety guidelines::: this is a formal notice. This reckless behavior is putting the campus experience and everyone‚Äôs health at risk. Therefore::: I want to make sure you are aware of the potential impacts to your educational experience. If you violate a public health order and the violation is connected to attending a party::: you will be excluded from campus for at least two weeks and you may be suspended. Multiple violations will result in suspension::: which means you‚Äôll be automatically withdrawn from classes and barred from access to campus resources.  Violations and sanctions If you are caught hosting or attending a party or large gathering on or off campus that violates a public health order::: you will be at a minimum:  Excluded from campus for two weeks. You will need to make arrangements to participate in your classes remotely. Placed on probation::: which impacts your ability to study abroad or attend graduate school. Required to participate in educational sanctions::: which will provide you additional information on following public health orders in the future. Multiple or severe violations will result in suspension from CU Boulder for a minimum of one semester.  If you are in a leadership position of an off-campus organization that hosts a party::: you may also be charged with aiding and abetting in other individuals‚Äô violations of public health orders in addition to facing the above sanctions.  If you have been excluded from campus and are found violating the exclusion::: the CU Police Department can issue a criminal trespass ticket and you will likely be suspended.  The city of Boulder and landlords also may take action against violators.  How to report We cannot take action without formal complaints and individual names being shared. If you witness an incident or other concerning behavior that puts public health at risk::: please report it to our conduct office. You must include a name and as much information as possible for us to be able to take action.  Help keep campus open Being a Buff means looking out for each other. And that includes making decisions that help prevent the spread of COVID-19.  Again::: I want to thank the majority of our students who are following public health orders and engaging in safe behaviors. We have amazing students on this campus and we appreciate all that you are doing to keep the campus safe.  Remember: you are a Buff wherever you are. Let‚Äôs work together to make this semester successful for everyone.  Sincerely:::  Akirah J. Bradley::: EdD Vice Chancellor for Student Affairs

column8: The reason people are scared is the media wants them to be scared.  As The Daily Wire reported Tuesday::: misinformation from mainstream media outlets has led many Americans to hold misconceptions about the risk of death from COVID-19. A study from Franklin Templeton Investments and Gallup Research found three major ways Americans misunderstand the death risk of COVID-19:  On average::: Americans believe that people aged 55 and older account for just over half of total COVID-19 deaths; the actual figure is 92%.  Americans believe that people aged 44 and younger account for about 30% of total deaths; the actual figure is 2.7%.  Americans overestimate the risk of death from COVID-19 for people aged 24 and younger by a factor of 50; and they think the risk for people aged 65 and older is half of what it actually is (40% vs 80%).

column1: We know it's smoky out there which may impact your health.  Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment put together a helpful guide to comparing symptoms of wildfire smoke inhalation and COVID-19.  Stay safe this wildfire season with these tips ‚û°Ô∏è https://colorado.edu/today/2020/08/20/fire-season-colorado-stay-informed-stay-safe  Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment August 19::: 2020 at 12:51 PM ¬∑  Not sure if your symptoms are from COVID-19 or wildfire smoke? While many symptoms overlap (e.g. cough::: scratchy throat)::: there are symptoms unique to COVID-19 ‚Äî for example::: fever::: chills::: and diarrhea.  If you have symptoms::: talk to your health care provider about getting tested for COVID-19.  People with lung conditions::: such as asthma and COPD::: may recognize the symptoms they have when smoke is in the air and might not need a COVID test.

There are currently at least four large active wildfires in the state of Colorado. Coupled with a need to spend more time outdoors due to physical distancing guidelines::: it's important to review these health and safety reminders. Learn how you can stay safe this wildfire season ‚û° https://bit.ly/2EmzaQw  COLORADO.EDU Fire season in Colorado: Stay informed::: stay safe

Typically found behind the camera capturing the photos that beautifully tell the CU story::: Forever Buff and university photographer Glenn hopped in front of the camera to tell you why protecting the herd is so important to him.  Learn more: www.colorado.edu/protect-our-herd

column13: Is this only upon arrival? Some schools (Univ of IL Urbana) are testing 2x/week‚Ä¶ From the NPR article..."And::: why two tests per week? Coronavirus diagnostic tests tend to catch people only during a short window when they're most infectious. So::: a newly infected person may test negative if the sample is taken too early::: before the virus has begun to replicate in their body. But::: if they're tested again a few days later::: the virus would likely be detected. "So::: by testing frequently the chances of catching that person when their viral load goes up is very high:::" Burke says."  I also think that the 2x/week testing can have a ‚Äúpositive‚Äù psychological effect of adhering to social distancing and wearing masks. Maybe Jane/Johnny Coed may decide to skip that party since she/he is getting tested in 2 days; and a positive test would mean quarantine.  https:// www.npr.org/ sections/ health-shots/ 2020/08/15/ 902616040/ can-testing-stud ents-for-corona virus-twice-a-w eek-prevent-cam pus-outbreaks

column1: Throughout the last few months::: under guidance from our world-class research and innovation teams in partnership with our dynamic and dedicated faculty and staff::: we worked together to create::: implement and now execute our Road Map to Fall.  A COVID-19-Ready campus experience and flexible academic instruction modalities are top priorities as we welcome Buffs back to campus for the fall 2020 semester. None of our in-person learning is possible without upgrades to our buildings and sanitation. We have spent millions of dollars investing in personal protective equipment::: air filtration systems and enhanced cleaning and disinfection protocols.  Serving the public good is more vital now than ever. With that in mind::: we've implemented changes to the student code of conduct and introduced a public health awareness campaign::: "Protect Our Herd"::: as a daily reminder of the basic actions we all must take to ensure the safety of our community.  This is just a fraction of the work we‚Äôve done over the last few months and moving forward we will continue to be flexible and adapt as new data::: innovations and capabilities become available.  Learn more about our COVID-ready return to campus plan from Chancellor DiStefano at the link below.  COLORADO.EDU From the Chancellor - Our COVID-19-ready return to campus

column1: UPDATE: Late Tuesday::: Immigration and Customs Enforcement rescinded its decision to require international students to transfer or leave the country if their colleges or universities held classes entirely online because of the pandemic.  ‚ÄúWe are pleased the ICE directive has been withdrawn::: and our international students can continue their studies without disruption:::‚Äù said Chancellor Philip DiStefano. ‚ÄúEveryone of our students::: including the thousands of students who come to our campus from other parts of the world can continue to count on our support during this challenging time.‚Äù  Read the full update here ‚û°Ô∏è https://www.colorado.edu/today/2020/07/14/cu-boulder-hails-ice-decision-drop-new-restriction-international-students  COLORADO.EDU University of Colorado signs on to actions supporting international students  University of Colorado Boulder July 14::: 2020 at 11:18 AM ¬∑  CU president Mark Kennedy and chancellors of the four campuses issued a statement opposing a July 6 Immigration and Customs Enforcement directive. The statement is in direct support of international students and for legal action against the directive prohibiting international students from remaining in the United States if they cannot take in-person classes this fall.  CU Boulder is reviewing opportunities to join amicus briefs.  The International Student and Scholar Services (ISSS) office at CU Boulder will host an online forum for students to ask questions at 9 a.m. on Thursday::: July 16. Invitations will be sent directly to international students.  To read the statement in its entirety::: click the link below.

column1: An international team::: which includes six faculty members from CU Boulder::: lays out evidence showing just how tenacious the pathogen behind COVID-19 can be. The group says it can likely drift through and survive in the air::: especially in crowded::: indoor spaces with poor ventilation like many bars and restaurants.  These experts have also been working with closely with campus officials as they prepare to welcome students::: faculty and staff back to CU Boulder this fall. When one of the students gets COVID::: the rest have to be quarantined for 14 days - how do they keep up with their in-person classes::: since they cannot be there live?  If a professor gets COVID::: that means all the students in all of their live in-person classes will have to be quarantined? Plus::: there will have to be a substitute teaching online during that time. What are the plans for this?  Basically::: we heard a lot of maybes::: should bes::: probably will do this....not a lot of firm answers and what sounded like the false assuption that COVID will not happen on campus - at least the plans for that eventuality were not discussed at much length. Anyone know any of this? Thank you!

column1: Forever Buff Aaron LaMaskin was initially drawn to the anthropology field due to an interest in studying other cultures. However::: throughout his studies he realized that this was an outdated notion of the field. The new anthropology is more self-reflective::: aiming to understand history and how we interact with each other from contemporary points-of-view.  Aaron compared old and new by focusing on the collaborative process the Santa Fe Museum of Indian Arts and Culture has with Southwest Native peoples. What he found is that by including contemporary themes like ‚Äútrapdoors‚Äù in the exhibit::: the museum allows for different perspectives and takes on the same material::: fostering::: as LaMaskin puts it::: ideological accessibility.  Learn more about this outstanding graduate and his process at the link below.  COLORADO.EDU Outstanding grad looks to trapdoors and emergency exits

column9: CV19 update to the Student Code of Conduct: F. 26 Violating university requirements or public health orders in place to reduce the risk of spreading infectious disease (See Appendix 4).  a. Failing to follow any and all applicable federal::: state::: and/or local public health orders. If multiple orders apply or in the event of conflict between or among them::: students are required to follow the most restrictive public health order.  b. Failing to follow University policies::: procedures::: and any other requirements in place to help reduce the risk of contracting or spreading infectious diseases.  c. To the extent consistent with University policy::: failing to comply with any additional or more specific actions required by a campus department::: unit::: or building proctor::: to limit the spread of infectious disease::: while participating in a program or activity::: utilizing a service or benefit::: or using University facilities.  d. Failing to abide by face covering requirements. If University policy::: procedures::: or other requirements and/or public health orders require wearing face coverings::: students are required to wear face coverings that cover the nose and mouth whenever indoors on campus and whenever outdoors on campus when physical distancing of six feet or more is not possible. This does not apply to: (1) offices when used only by one student with a closed door; (2) private living spaces such as the interior of an apartment or residence hall room and bathroom::: but not including communal living spaces that are accessible to all students in a building such as shared kitchens::: lounges::: or bathrooms; or (3) when a specific activity the student is participating in cannot be reasonably done while wearing a face covering with this exception applying only as long as the duration of the activity::: including but not limited to while brushing one‚Äôs teeth in a communal bathroom::: while eating in a University dining hall or center::: or while exercising in the University recreation center or other University recreation facility.  e. Failing to abide by gathering requirements. All on campus gatherings::: public or private::: must comply with applicable University policy::: procedure::: or other requirements and the most restrictive public health order in place. All off campus gatherings::: public or private::: must comply with the most restrictive public health order in place. For example::: if specific capacity or density limitations or guidelines are in place::: student must abide by those parameters.  APPENDIX 4: Student Infectious Disease Mitigation  1. Purpose and scope of Student Conduct Code F.26.:  a. The health and safety of members of theUniversity community are the primary concerns of the University. To this end::: we have instituted expectations for students pertaining to the mitigation of the spread of infectious disease.The University added F.26.::: which outlines prohibited conduct for students::: to provide the structures necessary to maintain an in-person academic experience::: while mitigating the spread of infectious disease.  b. The F.26. provision applies to all University students as defined in G.14. of the Student Code of Conduct.  c. The F.26. provision is based on recommendations and requirements found inPublic Health Orders issued from the ColoradoDepartm ent of Public Health and Environment::: and Boulder County Public Health. They are also based on University of Colorado policies.  2. Beyond the expectations found in F.26.::: and to mitigate the risk of spread of infectious diseases::: students are strongly encouraged to take personal responsibility for the health and safety of themselves and others by following these recommendations :  a. Educating oneself about the infectious disease and following all CDC guidelines. Information about the COVID-19 pandemic can be found here: i. https:// www.cdc.gov/ coronavirus/ 2019-ncov/ index.html.  b. Understanding the local::: regional::: and statewide recommendations . These can be found here: i. https:// www.colorado.gov /cdphe ii. https:// www.bouldercount y.org/ departments/ public-health/ iii. https:// bouldercolorado. gov/coronavirus  c. Understanding the campus expectations. These can be found here: i. https:// www.colorado.edu /coronavirus  d. If contacted by an individual performing contact tracing::: students are strongly urged to participate in a timely manner.  e. Monitoring public health orders and University policies and ensure that one is informed of their requirements and recommendations as they are updated.  3. Reasonable Accommodations to F.26. of this code:  a. If a student feels they may require an accommodation due to a disability in order to comply with all or parts of this policy::: they should contact Disability Services atdsinfo@Colora do.edu. Disability Services will go through normal accommodation process and provide a student with an accommodations letter if appropriate.  b. If a student feels they may require an accommodation due to religion or creed in order to comply with all or parts of this policy::: they should contact The Office of Institutional Equity and Compliance at cureport@colora do.edu.

column1: Originally a Texas state holiday::: Juneteenth is now celebrated annually on the 19th of June throughout the United States. It celebrates the day when Union Army General Gordon Granger read aloud the Emancipation Proclamation on June 19::: 1865::: in the city of Galveston::: Texas::: almost two and a half years after the Emancipation Proclamation had been passed.  The CU Boulder Today team caught up with Hillary Potter::: associate professor of ethnic studies and associate dean for inclusive practice at CU Boulder College of Arts & Sciences::: to glean insights and understanding about why Juneteenth is gaining momentum in the United States.  Read the interview and learn more about this celebratory day at the link below.  COLORADO.EDU Why is Juneteenth gaining momentum?
column3: The rest of the nation catches up with Texas.

Dear faculty::: staff and students:  Boulder County Public Health (BCPH) today announced 17 recent positive cases of COVID-19 in our community::: many involving CU Boulder students. According to disease investigators::: some cases are related to parties that occurred in the University Hill area from May 25 to June 4. Other cases are related to a protest march in Boulder on June 5::: the virus spreading among roommates::: individuals who recently traveled and other reasons.  First::: we ask that any CU Boulder community members with connections to the identified events review guidance from BCPH. Students can utilize campus Medical Services at Wardenburg Health Center to get tested or contact their primary care physician. Services through Wardenburg Health Center are confidential.  Second::: these positive cases demonstrate the vital importance of every one of us following public health guidance. Noncompliance has serious consequences and places our entire community and our ability to deliver our educational mission at risk.  Our university is doing its part to enable students to return to campus this fall. We will have testing. We will have contact tracing. We will have personal protective equipment. We are making our classrooms::: facilities and residence halls as safe as possible. Our faculty and staff have been working around the clock to update our courses and instructional approaches to enable students safely back on campus.  This concentration of cases could have likely been prevented if those involved ‚Äî particularly those hosting and attending parties ‚Äî had followed public health orders. We all need to live up to our responsibilities::: as some students are putting their own health and their own and other students‚Äô on-campus educational opportunities in jeopardy by engaging in behaviors that imperil the health and safety of our entire community. We are prioritizing the health and safety of our campus and the community. We will not stand idly by if students are unable or unwilling to meet their obligations. This includes educating students::: referring those who may have violated public health orders and university policies to a student conduct process and working with local public health officials to ensure that our campus and community's health is not compromised by the actions of a few.  We acknowledge the reality that living with COVID-19 means there will be positive cases::: which is why we have a detailed plan to mitigate the risks. During March::: April and May::: our campus increased communications with students about why and how to comply with state::: county and city orders. We will continue to step up these communications and other measures throughout the summer and fall::: including:  - Instructing campus community members that they must follow all public health orders::: including strict limits for any public or private gatherings  - Updating the Student Code of Conduct to reflect the necessity for behaviors that promote health and safety during the COVID-19 pandemic. This applies on and off campus and will include educational efforts and appropriate sanctions for non-compliance with public health orders.  - Adopting mandatory training for students::: faculty and staff that includes instruction on physical distancing::: wearing face coverings::: hand hygiene and sanitation.  - Collaborating with BCPH::: the City of Boulder and others to comprehensively address how a combination of increased public education and direct outreach::: along with enforcement measures::: can combine to influence the choices made in our community.  - Working with students::: faculty and staff who become infected or exposed to engage in contact tracing to prevent the further spread of the virus.  This plan will only work and we will only be able to stay safe this summer and successfully return to campus this fall if every member of our community fully embraces their individual responsibilities to keep themselves and others healthy.  We must all do our part to respect each other and keep each other safe. We must not endanger each other with behaviors that do not live up to the values of our Colorado Creed.  CU Boulder will do its part. We ask each person in our community to do theirs.  Phil DiStefano Chancellor  Link to letter: https://www.colorado.edu/chancellor/node/1059
